subject: psu-ng: Add in ability to get presence via GPIO
commitMessage:
psu-ng: Add in ability to get presence via GPIO

The device tree and entity-manager (D-Bus) properties have the power
supply GPIO presence lines named, so we can use those GPIO line names to
find the GPIO device to read for determining power supply presence.

Some systems have the power supply presence lines in a gpio-keys section
(notably IBM Rainier). To facilitate continued function while running
with a device tree that has not removed those device tree entries, allow
for a fallback to the old inventory D-Bus propertiesChanged or
interfaceAdded matches for presence.

Change-Id: I5002aa62e5b460463cc26328c889a3786b467a3c
Signed-off-by: B. J. Wyman <bjwyman@gmail.com>

Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1

It seems like you addressed the hard-coded device driver path comments by planning making it configurable.  However, that will be done in a separate commit.

I don't see that commit up for review yet.  Assuming you get two +1s, do you want to wait to merge this until that other commit is ready?  I'm not sure if merging this alone would break anyone with a non-IBM PSU?
Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 9:

> Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1
> 
> It seems like you addressed the hard-coded device driver path comments by planning making it configurable.  However, that will be done in a separate commit.
> 
> I don't see that commit up for review yet.  Assuming you get two +1s, do you want to wait to merge this until that other commit is ready?  I'm not sure if merging this alone would break anyone with a non-IBM PSU?

I was overly patient on waiting for CI to indicate SUCCESS, and forgot to change it from WIP to review.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-power/+/44456
I think this can merge before that. I am not aware of anyone that will currently be broken if this merges with that hardcoded device driver name.
Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 681b2a36e646b07c26fbdd2bae8f0ee1c4f3f930 by Shawn McCarney
you can assign this up above in the constructors initialization list (lines 27,28)
Ack
This seems a little dangerous.  Do you know the exact exception it is throwing?  Maybe you could just catch that one.
Um... oh dear, I did know at one point...
error requesting GPIO lines: Device or resource busy
Do we need an error log here, or is a journal message enough?
This is semi-foolishly ~stolen~ borrowed from phosphor-gpio-monitor/presence. I was thinking it could continue to just be a journal message.
We should eventually log a communication error, if the power supply is seen as present, but the bind fails, so we cannot communicate with it.
the rest of your vars are camelcase
Moo!
Done
present = presenceGPIO->read() ?
Read can return -1 I think.  Should that be handled here?  Or should it throw an exception instead?

Did I do something wrong here? 

If I cannot get that gpiod code to find the line, should I throw an exception, so that we go back to the inventory handling methods?

Am I forgetting some boolean logic conversion thing? Does -1 mean false?

I'm not sure what the correct error handling is.  I was just mentioning that -1 is a special return value indicating error, and this code is not checking for that.  -1 (like any non-zero number) will be true.  So this code will think it worked and the PSU is present.  If that is your intention, maybe add a comment about that?
That is not what I want, if -1 is returned, I don't think I should indicate it is present. I will check if > 0 for the present = true case.

This can throw an exception.  I think PSUManager::analyze() calls PowerSupply::analyze(), and the PSUManager method doesn't have a try/catch.  The PSUManager method is called by a timer.  Is the exception supposed to go all the way back to main and terminate the application?
I would expect things to be seriously broken if we reach this point and updatePresenceGpio() throws an exception. Terminate application seems like the right thing to do to me. Do you disagree?

It is certainly up to you, I was just pointing it out.

If you are going to be reading that GPIO periodically, and one exception takes down the app for all PSUs, that seems pretty severe.  But maybe if you don't know whether they are present the situation is really bad and re-starting the app is the way to go.

I didn't quite understand this comment.  We know it is a string based on the 'const std::string&' in the declaration.  Is the line name actually a number (like "16"), so specifying that it is in string format is important?

Also, I'm not sure what "gpio-line-name" is.  Is that the D-Bus or EM property?  Or a device tree keyword?
Shortin it to "The gpio-line-name..." and add in a link to https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/device-tree-gpio-naming.md ?
That is fine, or just saying it is the gpio-line-name from the device tree.  I just wasn't familiar with that term/property and didn't know where it was coming from.
Done
Temporary code?  Remove?
Ack
Done

Is there a scenario where this could be nullptr?  It looked like it was always set if the constructor succeeded, but just wanted to check.

The behavior of * is undefined if the unique_ptr is null.  e.g. could throw, or return a garbage pointer, ...
I think I will go with returning GPIOInterface* as suggested below.
Done

I was a little confused in the .cpp where both presenceGPIO and presenceGpio were used.  Would it  be possible to get rid of the bool, and just delete the presenceGPIO if you can't use it?  Then you can still use unique_ptr's bool operator to do:
if (presenceGPIO)

Yeah, I agree having two different data members whose names differ only in case is confusing.  Also, the OpenBMC coding conventions state that acronyms should be same case throughout (https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#naming-conventions).

Another option would be to adopt the standard convention of starting boolean variables with an is/was/are/does sort of prefix.  e.g. "isUsingGPIO" or "isUsingGPIOForPresence".

I like Matt's suggestion too, but you'll probably need to put an if check in getPresenceGPIO() to handle when the unique_ptr is nullptr.  Or you could change it to return a GPIOInterface* and put the responsibility on the caller to check for nullptr.
Oops! I think this resulted from flawed thinking in some rewriting to handle unit testing via GMock. :-/ (and failure to follow coding conventions).
Done

Nit: updatePresenceGPIO()

See coding conventions comment above.
Ack
Done
Temporary code to be deleted?  Same question for the other log 2 lines later.

I had thought about removing this, but it was DEBUG, and the default level is INFO.

This should only show up once, per power supply, on startup, if DEBUG is enabled in the journal configuration file(s).

Should I just remove it?
You don't have to.  I just looked like it might be temporary code used for testing this commit.
I removed the one below this.
Done

This could be nullptr if the property was not found or an exception was thrown when parsing properties.  It is also dereferenced on the following line to create the PowerSupply object.

Should the if on line 139 check to make sure this is not null?  Or if it can be null, should there be a separate local with a default value of "" like you did with the bind delay?
I was going for this to be allowed as null, to avoid another dependency issue with a separate repository.

OK, but when you dereference a null pointer (*presline) you get undefined behavior and probably a core dump right?  That was why I asked if you wanted to assign it a default value of "" or something.  Another option would be to make it a std::optional<std::string>, but either way you'd need to check if it had a value before using it (e.g. on line 155).
I think I handle this, similar to the binddelay, only defaulted a std::string to "".
Done
I am not quite sure how to handle this. I apparently missed that I had a FIXME in here.
You can leave the FIXME there if you want.  You'll just have to manually test that code branch then.
Need to add test for when GPIO read throws an exception?
Not quite expected, at this point, but perhaps that was a bad assumption.
What happens if the line name cannot be found?  Is line a zombie object, or does this throw an exception?
It looks like it can throw an exception, but for whatever reason, I cannot get that to happen and roll up (with changes).
Done
Should this throw instead of returning -1?  For other issues it looks like you throw an exception.  Do callers know to check for a -1 value?
Is this part of the reason my try/catch/throw above in the constructor failed to give me desired results?

Sorry, I'm not sure what you mean here.  The constructor above (in this file) doesn't have a try/catch?

I just meant that normally C functions return a special return code when they fail, and C++ functions throw an exception when they fail.  Mixing the two approaches in the same function seems a little confusing for the caller.  e.g. sometimes when it fails it throws and sometimes it returns -1.

That was probably confusing. I noted that I could get an exception while looking into the gpiod::find_line() call above in the constructor, so I added in a try/catch (not pushed yet), but failed to catch an exception, which lead down to here in this read function, and things do not work so good with the mix of throwing exceptions or returning -1.
Done
This doesn't happen if the inner try/catch re-threw the exception.  Is that what you want?
I think I had examined this and determined that was okay. I am not so sure you can release a line if the request failed.
I meant line.release() doesn't happen if line.get_value() throws.  You catch the exception but then rethrow.  Does the release need to happen in that scenario?
Um... oh!
Done
properties?  or property map?
Done
interfaces?  or interface map?
Done
I'm guessing this and bus.call(invMsg) below could throw an exception.  Is your plan that the caller must catch and handle those?
Should probably document how it handles errors.  Does it throw?  Return -1?  Both?
Both, I think... perhaps it should not be both?

Yeah, I think having one way of indicating an error would be better.  Normally (when exceptions are allowed) this is an exception in C++ code.

However, if you need to distinguish between critical and non-critical errors, then maybe you need both?
Done
Did you mean to leave this here, commented out?
No, I should have removed that, as the init is up above as Spinler had suggested.
Done
you can make this const.  Also bindDelay.
Ack
Local CI failures over in power_supply.cpp:48 if I make this const.
Done

since there isn't a {} arg in this, you probably don't need format:
    log<level::DEBUG>("bindDelayProp");
Done

Where I was stumbling with this is that it is a Constructor test, and I need to run the constructor to get the GPIOInterface into the MockGPIOReader in order to tell it that I want it to Throw an exception, which will be after the fact.
Nit: typo
Ack
Why is this here?
Done
I didn't see a response for this question.  Is the plan that the caller will handle the exception if getService() or bus.call() throws?

I am not sure how I missed this one.

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-power/blob/aacc2aafa5b599ca9719dcc174b966c976568ab1/utility.cpp#L36

I suppose this could throw an exception. I am thinking I would probably handle it similar to below, where an ERROR trace is tossed in the journal and the InternalFailure is logged.
Done
the is_method_error calls aren't needed anymore.  bus.call will just throw on any problems.
Done
Add the doxygen for the rest of this class?  (or I suppose remove this, to make it consistent)
Ack
this looks like the GPIOReader description?
As in I suppose this belongs over in util.hpp, not here?
Done

Changing the bindDelay (DelayBind) to just be a hardcoded value, rather than over-complicating things for data driven when probably not needed. See: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/43009/6//COMMIT_MSG#9
I kinda missed this before, but is it safe to hardcode the ibm-cffps driver name here, or may there be other users of this code?
Good point, since this is 'phosphor-power-supply' it is supposed to be a common app.  Should this be in the meson-generated configuration file?

I sort of thought about this when I put in the path, but are we over-engineering things? I already changed bindDelay from EM to hardcoded.

I suppose some kind of meson-generated string would work, but just have the one for now.
I'll defer to Matt on this one.
OK, sounds like your stance is this code only works with IBM power supplies.

Well, no, not quite... I suppose this should probably be some kind of meson configuration option to fill in a constant or something like that.

We already have the IBM_VPD, should that perhaps be re-engineered to just cover a bunch of IBM type power supply things? CCIN for inventory, and InputHistory are most likely unique to IBM Common Form Factor Power Supplies (IBMCFFPS), as would be the IBMCFFPSConnector.

Would some kind of IBM configuration option turn on the IBM_VPD, input history, and sent some constants like bindPath and ... psuConnectorName?
That sounds reasonable.  You could probably do that in a separate commit if you so desired.
At this point, I think I would desire doing the more configurable path as a separate commit.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-power/+/44451
Nit: Should probably be const (e.g. const std::exception& e)
Ack
Oops! Did not push up a change to address this.
Done
